Problem:
Consider a mapping defined by the integral transform \\( X(s) = \\int_0^{\\infty} x(t) e^{-st} dt \\) where x(t) is a time-dependent function and s is a complex parameter. We explore how changes in the time-domain function influence the result of the integral transform and vice versa.

If the function \\( x(t) \\) is modified at time t = 0 (say, multiplied by a constant factor), and the resultant transform \\( X(s) \\) is observed without other interventions, will the characteristic features (like poles and zeros) of \\( X(s) \\) derived at t = T look the same as if \\( x(t) \\) was not modified?
Explanation: Modifying \\( x(t) \\) at t = 0 changes the entirety of the time-domain function which consequently alters the Laplace Transform. The multiplication by a constant factor will scale the transform but can significantly shift the poles or zeros especially if reactive elements (like integration or differentiation in \\( x(t) \\)) are present.
